results.title: Is it hot in here?: a film about menopause
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor, Jennifer Torrance, Haida Paul and Laura Alper
results.brief_description: With humor sometimes tinged with ruefulness, a group of women discusses menopause, sexuality, and how it feels to be aging in a society consecrated to youth. The film also examines how the medical profession is influenced by the pharmaceutical industry’s advertising, and underscores the need for women to become educated health consumers.

results.title: Is anybody doing anything about it?
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Richard Mason and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description: A dramatised introduction to the work of the Bureau of Meteorology, showing how weather information is collected and used for reports and predictions, with impressions of the importance of the weather in various industries. Shows how at the Southern Hemisphere Analysis Centre in Melbourne, synoptic charts are drawn up by computers. A global weather pattern can be seen every six hours. Cast features Carmen Duncan and Tom Oliver.

results.title: Irrigation farming
results.brief_description: Land without water is arid and desert, unable to support vegetation; humans, by their ingenuity, are able to bring water to irrigate such land; engineers harness melting mountain snows, and divert and dam rivers, and farmers use pipes, ditches, canvas, and channels to carry the water to the roots of their crops and pastures.

results.title: Irrigation
results.brief_description: Green acres instead of parched earth - that is the satisfying aftermath of the construction of the St. Mary Dam Reservoir in southwestern Alberta. The film describes the irrigation system that now distributes life-giving water to farmland that was often stricken by drought.

results.title: Ironbark Bill (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, Don Ezard and Philip Pepper
results.brief_description: This animated tale tells a raunchy, rocky, hilarious story of the legendary Ironbark Bill and the Champion Buckjumper, a high-spirited horse who bounces so high in his bucking that rider and horse end up in the clouds. The problem, then, is how to get down. It is based on Australian writer, Dal Stivens’ “Ironbark Bill” tall tales.

results.title: Iron shoes and granite tracks
results.creator_credit: Victorian Railways Board and Ted Davis
results.brief_description: Preparing for the summer season at the Mount Buffalo Chalet is a busy time. The ponies are brought up from the valley below where they had been on agistment during the winter. The stables are made ready and the riding gear dusted and cleaned in readiness for the visitors. Horse riding through the scenic countryside of Mount Buffalo is a popular holiday recreation.

results.title: Iron ore
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Eric Thompson and Joe Scully
results.brief_description: A survey of the mining, transporting and use of iron ore in the steel industry at Whyalla and Port Kembla. Indicates the various unused deposits of iron ore, especially in Western Australia.
